body:

title: I2C start for LPC812 (and LPC824)
Fix and enable the PLL for the LPC812
body:
The LPC812 was running on the IRC at 12MHz rather than at the rated and expected 30MHz. The PLL settings were fixed and the MainClock and SystemCoreClock calculation was fixed.
The serial_api was fixed to use the correct MainClock value. Enjoy a speed increase of 2.5 !

and TARGET_NUCLEO_F103RB.

Files stm32f10x_xxx.c(h) are same for both boards.
With this commit both boards use same files.
This is align with TARGET_STM32F0, TARGET_STM32F3 and  TARGET_STM32F4.

title: KSDK HAL - analogout - should use KSDK
body:
The analogout is implemented by using registers, as there was no DAC HAL in KSDK. This should be updated to use DAC HAL from KSDK.

Code snippet from the current implementation 

```
    DAC0->C1 = DAC_C1_DACBFMD(2);     // One-Time Scan Mode

    DAC0->C0 = DAC_C0_DACEN_MASK      // Enable
             | DAC_C0_DACSWTRG_MASK   // Software Trigger
             | DAC_C0_DACRFS_MASK;    // VDDA selected
```

title: Add a new target DELTA_DFCM_NNN40
body:
Hi,

There is  a new target( DELTA_DFCM_NNN40 ) that we want to add into your platform.
We are Delta company. And We manufacture a BLE WiFi combo module.
We use NRF51822 BLE+M0 chip.  It is configured to 32MHz X'tal and use 32K RC crystal oscillator.
The module supports OTA update FW so it is necessary to create another target to support OTA like Nordic nRF51822 FOTA.

Thanks
Marco

title: RTOS Compiler Warning
body:
Compiling the RTOS library in the online compiler is currently issuing the following compiler warning:

```
Warning: A value of type "unsigned char *" cannot be assigned to an entity of type "uint32_t *" in "mbed-rtos/rtx/TARGET_CORTEX_M/RTX_CM_lib.h", Line: 319, Col: 38
```

I believe this may be a result of pull request #812, which changed `osThreadDef_t.stack_pointer` to a `uint32_t*` type.

title: Fixes to get LPC4330 GCC based builds to run
body:
I was getting Hard Faults in even the simplest of samples before I made
these fixes.
- WaitUs() did nothing on optimized builds.  I added the volatile
  qualifier to the cyc variable to make sure that the delay loop
  doesn't get optimized out.
- I removed the #ifdef which skipped the fpuInit() call when building
  with GCC.

title: [EXPORT][TEENSY3_1] Added uVision Teensy3.1 exporter
body:
Copy paste of K20D50M code, pretty sure I modified the most important
bits.

It runs the exporter from command line without errors, I can open the resulting uVision project, it has the correct device selected, pretty sure I got correct memories also in it (IROM, IRAM), it is set to also generate a hex file, and last but not least, if I then compile my own blinky program in Keil uVision 5 it compiles properly and even blinks the LED!

Also someone should make a readme on how to make those exporter files.

title: [LPC1114] remove reset pin name to protect people. [LPC824] I2C pin names were crossed
body:
On LPC1114 platforms, if user set P0_0 as DigitalOut and set it to low, LPC1114 will be in reset condition. To avoid this situation, p4, xp4 and dp23 was removed from PinNames.h.

On LPC824 platforms, I2C pin names were crossed.

title: Add readme.html to every exported project
body:
# Problem

Some offline exporters are having issues, (Think BLE and the need for a 3rd party flash algorithm with Keil V4), currently there is no good way to help people out
# Solution

Add a readme.html to every offline exporter that redirects people to a page where we keep a list of the known errata for each platform and compiler. Part of the web address is the platform and compiler so they will automatically jump down the page to where their platform and compiler are.

title: switching timestamp_t back to 32-bits.
body:
The underlying us_tickers used for comparison are still 32-bits; keeping a 64-bit timestamp isn't going to be useful.

fixes #838

title: let's switch back to 32-bit timestamp_t
body: Having 64-bit arithmetic for timestamp_t isn't helping. Using a 64-bit timestamp we can't really set a timeout which won't get captured within 32-bits anyway; because the underlying timers are 32-bit.

title: [NUCLEO_F070RB] Update tests with this target
[build_release.py] Adding GCC_ARM toolchain to some Nucleo targets
body: Adding GCC_ARM toolchain to some Nucleo targets

title: [RZ_A1H]Fix some bugs about InterruptIn, SPI, I2C and modify some settings.
body:
Hi,

We fixed some bugs and modify some settings as below.

InterruptIn
- Add terminal setting of IRQ4 and IRQ6 that leaked.
- When set the interrupt function by rise()/fall(), the interrupt disable state will be released by disable_irq().
- Interrupt will be continued to occur when execute disable_irq() after rise(NULL)/fall(NULL) set.
- Fix the setting timing of PMC register.

SPI
A noise will occur when execute frequency() after set the "mode" to 3 by format().

I2C
Implement a stop condition transmission setting function of I2C.
User can specify the sending of STOP condition by this implement.

scatter file
Update scatter file to increase usable RAM area.
Remove a usable RAM area limit of RW and ZI area.

RTOS
Increase STACK size of thread.

device.h
Take measures about optimization problems of web compiler.

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: Add Freescale MCU Target MK20DX256VLH7 and Teensy3.1 Platform Board
body:
Introducing Teensy3.1 to Mbed 

The porting of this Target MCU along with the Teensy3.1 Platform board project has been produced in collaboration with Erik Olieman and myself. It has been developed by using parts of the Mbed-SRC K20D50M libraries and successfully compiles using FRDM-K2D50M as the target (with reduced Flash and RAM specifications).

Both the K20D50M and K20DX256 MCU's have now been combined to share library code as much as possible and the library structure simplifies the process for other K20 MCU's to be added at a later stage and is the same format as the KLxx series MCU's.

The code has been built and tested for both MCU's, the K20D50M will build a uVision project as it did before combining the code, however the K20DX256 does not as it requires a uVision export definition file but does compile in command line.

Erik Olieman's Serial API fractional code fix for the K20D50M (also used on the K2DX256) has transformed the serial functionality that has been tested beyond 256k baud, a vast improvement on the KLxx series MCU's.

The TARGET_TEENSY3_1 has been set to output .hex to facilitate code download using the Teensy Loader program. This means that the download process is two stage. Further information is available here:

https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/loader_vista.html

The download to MCU process takes around 1 second for a 97k code size.

There are two remaining todo's
1. Fix the PWM api that has a slight issue on both targets (inherited from the Mbed K20D50M code).
2. Add CAN api
This be will more straightforward to accomplish when it is live on Mbed where we do not have to add the .bin to .hex code conversation stage.

I am in the process of producing the Teensy3.1 board Pin out drawings and detailed information that will be available in the next two days. 

Meanwhile here is a picture of the Teensy3.1, a long awaited addition to the Mbed platforms.

![teensy-3_1_exp-r05-439_4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6283197/5638621/660687a2-9601-11e4-9ec6-4aee1581b3c8.jpg)

Paul Staron

title: RTX: Main thread should not write MAGIC_WORD to stack
body:
This is a fix for issue #285.  This fix is similar to that proposed by
@oresths in the original issue.

There is code in rt_init_stack() which compares the task_id against the
value of 1 before writing MAGIC_WORD to the bottom of the stack.  This
is supposed to stop the write from occurring for the main thread but
svcThreadCreate() doesn't initialize the P_TCB's task_id field until
after rt_init_stack() is executed.  If any dynamic memory allocation
has occurred before the main thread is started (from the standard C
startup code) then this write could overwrite data in that allocation.

This change:
- moves the task_id initialization in svcThreadCreate() to happen
  before the call to rt_init_context() is made.
- cleans up some comments in svcThreadCreate() which appear to
  reference older versions of the code which would automatically
  allocate stack memory if size == 0.
- still keeps the call to rt_dispatch() occurring after the call to
  rt_init_context() so that the task is not dispatched to the
  scheduler until the task fields have been populated.

I stepped through the rt_init_stack() code on my mbedLPC1768 after this
change was made to make sure that the write of MAGIC_WORD is now
skipped.

```
(gdb) break HAL_CM.c:95
Breakpoint 1 at 0x482c: file ../../external/mbed/libraries/rtos/rtx/TARGET_CORTEX_M/HAL_CM.c, line 95.
(gdb) c
Continuing.
Note: automatically using hardware breakpoints for read-only addresses.

Breakpoint 1, rt_init_stack (p_TCB=0x10000774 <os_idle_TCB>, task_body=0x4899 <os_idle_demon>)
    at ../../external/mbed/libraries/rtos/rtx/TARGET_CORTEX_M/HAL_CM.c:95
95    if (p_TCB->task_id != 0x01)
(gdb) p *p_TCB
$1 = {
  cb_type = 0 '\000',
  state = 1 '\001',
  prio = 0 '\000',
  task_id = 255 '\377',
  p_lnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  p_rlnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  p_dlnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  p_blnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  delta_time = 0,
  interval_time = 0,
  events = 0,
  waits = 0,
  msg = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  stack_frame = 0 '\000',
  reserved = 0 '\000',
  priv_stack = 128,
  tsk_stack = 268437480,
  stack = 0x100007a8 <idle_task_stack>,
  ptask = 0x4899 <os_idle_demon>
}
(gdb) c
Continuing.

Breakpoint 1, rt_init_stack (p_TCB=0x10000120 <os_thread_def_main+16>, task_body=0x620d <__wrap_main()>)
    at ../../external/mbed/libraries/rtos/rtx/TARGET_CORTEX_M/HAL_CM.c:95
95    if (p_TCB->task_id != 0x01)
(gdb) p *p_TCB
$2 = {
  cb_type = 0 '\000',
  state = 1 '\001',
  prio = 4 '\004',
  task_id = 1 '\001',
  p_lnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  p_rlnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  p_dlnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  p_blnk = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  delta_time = 0,
  interval_time = 0,
  events = 0,
  waits = 0,
  msg = 0x0 <_reclaim_reent>,
  stack_frame = 0 '\000',
  reserved = 0 '\000',
  priv_stack = 26968,
  tsk_stack = 268467136,
  stack = 0x100012a8,
  ptask = 0x620d <__wrap_main()>
}
(gdb) n
97  }
```

When the p_TCB for ptask==__wrap_main() is encountered, the task_id
now has a value of 1 and the write of MAGIC_WORD on line 96 is
skipped.

title: RTX: Support stacks larger than 64k
body:
This issue was originally reported on the mbed site:
 http://developer.mbed.org/questions/5570/mbed-rtos-memory-utilization/

The cause of the 64k limitation is that even though the user can set a
stack size larger than 64k in the osThreadDef_t::stacksize 32-bit
field, this size is truncated to 16-bit when it is copied to
the priv_stack field in the OS_TCB structure.

This commit corrects that problem by making the OS_TCB::priv_stack
field 32-bit.  Due to word alignment, this introduces another 2 bytes
of padding in the structure which I have made explicit with the
addition of the reserved2 field.

The tsk_stack field which follows priv_stack is referenced directly by
assembly language code responsible for context switching.  This context
switching code used a fixed byte offset, TCB_TSTACK, to access this
tsk_stack field.  I had to update the TCB_TSTACK definition in various
locations from 36 to 40 to account for the extra alignment padding and
increased size of the priv_stack field.

TESTING
- GCC_ARM - mbedLPC1768 and mbedLPC11U24
- Online mbed Compiler - mbedLPC1768 and mbedLPC11U24

NOTES: I had to change assembly language code that was specific to IAR
       but I don't have that toolchain so those changes aren't tested.
       They do however follow the same pattern as the tested GCC
       modifications.

I also didn't touch the Cortex-A version of RTX since I don't have such hardware to perform any testing.

title: [DISCO/NUCLEO_L053xx] adding to RTOS, corrections for all tests, [DISCO_L053] exporter to Vision
body:
Adding both targets to be able to run RTOS:
- changing default STM32Cube startup files to call _start instead of __libc_init_array and main
- extending RTX config and adding targets to RTOS_x tests in tests.py
- reducing stack sizes forthis target because of 8k RAM

Correcting the stdio uart config.

Solving the RTC start problem at DISCO_L053 target. Perhaps it is a hardware problem at the mcu when no 32kHz crystal is connected:
The mcu STM32L053C8 seems to have a problem in the RCC - LSE hardware block. The Disco_L053 don't have a 32kHz crystal connected to LSE port pins in contrast to NUCLEO_L053.
During initialization the HAL tests if it can start the LSE oscillator. The Flag LSERDY in RCC_CSR is set to 1 by RCC clock control when the oscillator runs stable. Without a crystal the flag shouldn't be set and the HAL would try to start the internal LSI oscillator.
But the flag is always set to 1 also without a crystal. 
That's why the RTC doesn't start. The suggested solution is starting the RTC directly with the internal LSI oscillator.

Every test (DTCT_1, EXAMPLE_1, MBED_xx, RTOS_x) is OK.

title: [RZ_A1H]Modify frequency setting processing of SPI
body:
Hi,

We midified frequency setting processing of SPI.
In case of off-line compiler, there is no problem about the frequency setting processing.
But in case of online compiler, the frequency setting processing will be error.
So, modify frequency setting processing of SPI to pass in online compiler.

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: us_ticker_read() return a 0xFFFF  less  value for STM32F103RB.

title: Fix KL05Z GCC_ARM linker script
body:
Issue originally reported on mbed site here:
https://developer.mbed.org/questions/5695/FRDM-KL05z-hardfault-when-compiled-with-/

The RAM base address was incorrectly set to the beginning of RAM
instead of at a 0xC0 byte offset to reserve room for the interrupt
vectors. Without this fix, the global variables and the interrupt
vectors were occupying the same space in RAM once the user enabled the
timer interrupt.

The user who originally reported the issue on the mbed site has tested
this fix and verified that it corrected the hard fault issue that they
were encountering.

title: Updated README.md to be up date with IAR's target support
Fix stack aligment.
body:
Stack should be 8 byte aligned on ARM.
Fix the automatic correction of the alignment in rt_init_stack,
and make sure that all stacks are aligned by the compiler.

title: fix HAL_NULL, add more GPIO_CLK macros
[RZ_A1H] Fix some drivers bugs and modify some settings of OS and
body:
Hi,

We fixed some drivers bugs and modified some settings of OS and Ether as below.

I2C
- Frequency accuracy improvement
- Changed the wait time between one communication completed and the next communication start.
  The wait time will be Low clock width by this changing.

PWM
- Modify processing of pulsewidth() to match the specifications of the RZ_A1H.

SPI
- Frequency accuracy improvement
- Modify transfer processing when transfer bit length is 16bit or 32bit.

Serial
- Change the reference register macro to align with other driver codes.

Setting of OS and Ether
- Change default setting of CMSIS-RTOS RTX for Cortex-A9 to align with Cortex-M.
- Change the interrupt priority of Ether driver to align with other drivers.

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: [DISCO_F429ZI] clock frequency
body:
Original STM32Cube F4 driver sets SYSCLK for STM32F429 to 16MHz. This adds a 168MHz and 180MHz configuration to system_stm32f4xx.c generated by STM32CubeMX code generator. The rtos clock configuration is changed too. In singletest.py run everything is OK.

Perhaps @bcostm wants to inform the STM32Cube people about the wrong configuration of their fastest mcu running only with 16MHz not only in the driver template but also in the examples.

title: About common wait processing
body:
Hi,

We want to discuss about wait processing.
We found a problem of wait_us() in wait_api.c.
If the value "start" is 0xFFFFFFFF, the code as below will be infinite loop, isn't it?

```
while ((us_ticker_read() - start) < (uint32_t)us);
```

We think the problem can fix by changing return value type of us_ticker_read function to uint64_t.
Please consider our proposal.

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: [api] AnalogIn member updates
body:
While updating the AnalogIn documentation I came across a few problems with the API. read_u16 is defined to return a normalized value (16bit) while the actual implementations don't seem to respect this (some do, most don't). I think the reason for inconsistency is due to lack of documentation in the C HAL. The API is also lacking standard access to the converted value regardless of the underlying peripheral result size.

This branch is my proposal to update the API. It will require changes in the C HAL as well (not shown in commit). There should also be a test written that compares the read_uXX to the normalized value from read to ensure the members are implemented correctly

https://github.com/sg-/mbed-os/commit/c152fd4d7ce2cb5d217821206de424818a932ce8

title: [RZ_A1H]Add the timer value wraparound processing to us_ticker
body:
Hi,

We add the timer value wraparound processing to us_ticker.
Timer value wraparound operation had not been considered in us_ticker.
So, User could not set upper than 128s to argument of wait().

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: [NUCLEO_L053R8] Removed call to Systick (mbed RTOS compliancy)
body: Fix #601 issue

title: [RZ_A1H]Add the timer value wraparound processing to common wait processing
body:
Hi,

We add the timer value wraparound processing to common wait processing.
Timer value wraparound operation had not been considered in common wait process.
By defining the EXPIRE_US non-zero value, wraparound operation is enabled.
The EXPIRE_US will be define the value of each vender-specific.
If EXPIRE_US is 0, the common wait process is same as before.
Please check the code.

And, fix a bug that us_ticker count clock will be truncated after the decimal point.

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: Iar mbed
body:
Separated the c data initialization and c++ to call mbed_sdk_init before c++ data. So that the c variables are updated before the c++ objects are initialized. Had to rename the cmain override in RTX_CM_lib.h to
 __iar_program_start because there can not be two __cmain overrides in the project. The ewps had to be updated to add the linker command --skip_dynamic_initialization which stalls the c++ data init until __iar_dynamic_initialization which is called right after mbed_sdk_init.

title: With the old logic if Serial::writeable() was called before and/or used ...
body: ...to block calls to Serial::putc() it would never write due to EVENT_TXDRDY trailing a write to TXD. Add a dummy write to TXD before pins are connected to the peripheral. This primes the EVENT_TXDRDY to lead future writes rather than trail. Since STOPTX isn't used this seems safe.

title: Fixed linker files (Ram size on one) and for the rest increased the heap...
body: ... and stack size

title: Targets: Freescale KSDK - extern } syntax error fix
body: This should fix #765 issue

title: Problem with RTOS_1 on STM32F4DISCOVERY
body:
I have an STM32F1DISCOVERY (Cortex-M3) and an ...F4... (Cortex-M4). I have compiled the RTOS_1 example for both. 

The example works only on the F1, i.e. I see the two LEDs blinking with the expected frequencies. On the F4, LED1 is turned on, after that nothing happens.

Tracking this down I found that the problem is in /mbed-tools/libraries/rtos/rtx/TARGET_CORTEX_M/TARGET_M4/TOOLCHAIN_GCC/HAL_CM4.s. Thread::wait (called from main) eventually issues an svc for waiting. So we come to SVC_Handler. At the beginning of the SVC_Handler we have "MRS R0,PSP". On the F1, this loads the stack pointer into R0 as expected. On the F4, its loads 0 into R0. Any idea what's going wrong here?

title: [HAL][K20D50M] Serial baudrate improvements / clk_freqs.h fix
body:
Three changes, first it fixes:
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/761 (which was reported
slightly wrong because K20 has again different clocking from KLXX for
uarts).

Second it adds mcgpllfll to clk_freqs, which again is different for K20
compared to KLXX .

Finally it adds the fractional baudrate divider for more accurate serial
baudrates.

Downside of all this: High frequency communication via USBTX/USBRX doesn't work properly since the interface chip isn't use the fractional divider so has inaccurate baudrate. However users can always give an offset to the baudrate to 'fix' this.

Also this one can be automatically merged :D. Pretty sure stuff is correct now, but at least better than it was.

title: IAR memory model
body: @GustavWi It doesn't appear that the ST targets (and maybe others?) are following the [Memory Model](http://developer.mbed.org/handbook/Memory-Model) that the other compilers do.  The IAR linker has fixed stack and heap regions, rather than fluid sizes.  Can you figure out a way to make the IAR targets match?
